channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Former SNP leader Alex Salmond launches new political party
item.description: The former first minister said the pro-independence Alba Party would field candidates across Scotland.

item.title: Slight Covid uptick in older school children in England
item.description: Latest figures from the ONS hint at an increase in years 7 to 11 in schools in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: Germany tightens borders amid alarm over pandemic
item.description: There could be 100,000 infections a day if the third Covid wave spreads unchecked, Germans are warned.

item.title: Coronavirus: France accuses UK of 'blackmail' over vaccine exports
item.description: The row over Covid vaccination supplies escalates after France's foreign minister criticises the UK.

item.title: Suez Canal: Ships stuck in 'traffic jam' as salvage efforts continue
item.description: The queue has "grown exponentially" since a container vessel ran aground, a sailor says.

item.title: Asda workers win key appeal in equal pay fight
item.description: Supreme Court rules shop workers are free to pursue fight to gain equal pay with warehouse staff.

item.title: Major general jailed for Dorset school fees fraud
item.description: Maj Gen Nick Welch claimed to live in London rather than in Dorset near his children's schools.

item.title: Batley Grammar School: Prophet Muhammad cartoon row 'hijacked'
item.description: Robert Jenrick defends the right of teachers to "appropriately" show images of the Prophet Muhammed.

item.title: Uighurs: UK MPs banned by China vow to 'redouble' efforts against human rights abuses
item.description: Five sanctioned parliamentarians say they will continue to campaign for persecuted groups in China.

item.title: Xinjiang cotton: Western clothes brands vanish as backlash grows
item.description: Companies including H&M and Nike are targeted for showing concern over Uighur forced labour claims.

item.title: Burglar and victims become friends through rehabilitation scheme
item.description: Anne Linton and a man who burgled her swap Christmas gifts and he regularly does her gardening.

item.title: Braunton boy sleeping outside invites children on 'big camp-out'
item.description: Max Woosey, 11, is inviting children around the world to join him in a camp-out on Saturday night.

item.title: Prince Albert II: Harry and Meghan interview 'did bother me'
item.description: Prince Albert II of Monaco has weighed in on the controversial interview that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle gave to Oprah Winfrey.

item.title: Wockhardt UK: Inside the factory making the AstraZeneca vaccine
item.description: BBC Breakfast has been given a world-first look inside the Covid vaccine factory Boris Johnson called "the saviour of humanity".

item.title: 999 response officers receive extra psychological support
item.description: Police forces are offering extra psychological support to 999 response officers.

item.title: Mina Smallman: 'I know what Sarah Everard's parents are experiencing'
item.description: Nicole Smallman and Bibaa Henry's mother says the loss of her children left her "broken beyond words".

item.title: The Papers: UK 'plans October booster jab' and pub passport 'fury'
item.description: People being offered boosters to protect against new Covid strains features on Friday's front pages.

item.title: 'My brother died fighting for Senegal’s youth'
item.description: Thousands of young people took to the streets earlier this month, in anti-government protests.

item.title: Winslet's same-sex role 'simply a love story'
item.description: Oscar-winning actress Kate Winslet’s latest role sees her as the 19th Century fossil hunter Mary Anning.

item.title: Bafta Games Awards 2021: Hades takes Best Game
item.description: The Ancient Greek action adventure won big on the night with five awards in total.

item.title: Xinjiang cotton: How do I know if it's in my jeans?
item.description: It's at the centre of a row between Western brands and China over allegations of forced labour.

item.title: Rough sleepers: Long-term housing 'varies by area'
item.description: Some people have been housed after years on the streets, but others still face uncertainty.

item.title: Suez Canal: How are they trying to free the Ever Given?
item.description: Operations are continuing to move a 400 metre long vessel stuck in the Suez Canal since Tuesday.

item.title: Welsh elections 2021: Will 16 and 17-year-olds vote?
item.description: The age of voting has reduced in Wales to 16 but how many of this age group will cast their ballot?

item.title: Coronavirus and shielding: 'I've only left my home five times this year'
item.description: Michaela Hollywood led a jet-set lifestyle until coronavirus hit, then she had to shield.

item.title: Learning to code 'will seriously change your life'
item.description: Software developers are in high demand and well paid, but how do you break into the industry?

item.title: Promising Young Woman: Carey Mulligan film 'deeply troubling'
item.description: Promising Young Woman, starring Carey Mulligan, is a dark and twisted take on "hook-up culture".

item.title: US immigration: The suffocated youth unafraid of a perilous journey
item.description: Tougher policies and deaths on the road are unlikely to stop Guatemalans from trying to reach the US.

item.title: Bangladesh at 50: Why my ancestral home could be lost to climate change
item.description: As Bangladesh turns 50, a UK-Bangladeshi reflects on how climate change affects his parent's country.

item.title: The unusual death of Colin Marr
item.description: The police said he took his own life after a row with his fiancée - but his family say questions still remain about how he died.

item.title: I will 'definitely' win rematch - Whyte vows to stop Povetkin in Gibraltar
item.description: British heavyweight Dillian Whyte says he will "definitely" avenge his shock defeat by Alexander Povetkin in their rematch on Saturday.

item.title: Everton FC's £500m stadium plan approved by government
item.description: The club says its plans for a 52,000 capacity stadium have been approved by the secretary of state.

item.title: FA Cup semi-final: BBC to broadcast Chelsea v Man City at Wembley
item.description: The FA Cup semi-final between Chelsea and Manchester City at Wembley will be broadcast live on the BBC on Saturday, 17 April.

item.title: World Cup 2026: Are USA building towards success on home soil in 2026?
item.description: With a thriving system producing players for various Champions League teams, the US look set to be a threat in the 2026 World Cup they will co-host.

item.title: England captain Houghton out for 'minimum of two to three weeks'
item.description: Manchester City and England captain Steph Houghton will miss a minimum of two-three weeks with an Achilles injury.

item.title: Covid passports: What are different countries planning?
item.description: How advanced are some countries' plans for vaccine certificates and Covid passports?

item.title: Where is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine made?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland are easing restrictions on people meeting, and changes are due in England on Monday.

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Covid rules: What is the rule of six in England?
item.description: The rule of six is back for England from Monday but with some changes - we explain what they are.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as almost 29 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Does the Oxford vaccine have a blood clot problem? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport to go to the pub or travel abroad?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: India coronavirus: Why have vaccine exports been suspended?
item.description: India is a big player in vaccine production - but companies are warning of supply problems.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Side effects and why it can’t give you the virus
item.description: It's normal to experience some mild side effects, such as a headache or a raised temperature.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid: More walking and family chats post-lockdown - poll suggests
item.description: We've done more walking and worked more from home this year, according to a BBC-commissioned poll.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: 'My father, the killer'
item.description: Some of the children of men who helped to "disappear" thousands of Argentines in the 1970s and 80s are now speaking out - against their fathers.
